I found your essay on Research in the Newer Educational Media of great
help, and reading it makes it appear even more obvious to me, that the
obsession with content analysis in psychological testing of media is
itself a subliminal factor carried over from unconscious patterning of
mind from print technology. One has only to say this in order to see
that a mind which has accustomed itself to codifying experience vis¬
ually, on the page, becomes completely unaware of the packaging device
so employed, and thinks of content as a completely dominant fact, and
of vehicle and container as unimportant, relatively, as features*
I think my Gutenberg book will offer a sufficient quantity and continuity
of testimony on the effects of the forms of writing and printing to make
this completely convincing, because one has only to consult the changes
in the arts of poetry, and prose, and painting under the impact of var¬
ious developments in print technology, to trace the exact lines of
force which that technology exerts* This raises a very basic question
about media research*
I mean the factor of translation from one language .into another as a
revealer of the properties of both, so that as Rene Clair put it in a
Tv show a few months ago, when two people appear on the stage, it is
necessary that the dramatist motivate and explain their presence there.
Whereas the movie camera can look at anything, or follow any group in
action without the slightest need for an explanation of why it chooses
to do so* The grammar of the camera eye, what it includes and excludes,
is best scene when it encounters another medium. The same is true of
poetry and painting. The problem of arranging images verbally, of
creating time and space situations, and point of view, tone and attir
tude is quickly revealed when a poem attempts to present some of the
effects of a visual composition* In other words, if the new media
are also new languages having specific and limited powers of statement
and codification, these are most quickly revealed in their profiles
or grammars, or lines of force and reality by Juxtaposition and inter¬
penetration. Thus the movies have learned fast about themselves through
having to produce for TV purposes. Radio learned about its unique
properties, and its Indispensable contribution only after TV smacked
into it. From this point of view, may it not prove feasible for me
by questionnaire and interview to extract from the technicians in the
various media a testimony of what has been revealed to them concerning
their media since the impact of rival media. In short, why can we not
sift the innumerable anecdotes from within the media world as a kind
of Involuntary evidence concerning media contours*
As a final overall observation, is it not plain that understanding media
means the raising of the subliminal levels of all media experience for
inspection and scrutiny. Is it not equally plain that our century as
an all-at-once century has accepted the challenge of the elimination
of the subliminal on all fronts. This of course is what is meant by
saying the medium is the message” because it is only by abstraction
of the specific literate type that we ever came to think of the message
as separate from the vehicle. In an all at once world of Ulanovas and
